title: Tippmann X-7 / X7 Phenom Front Shroud

description.text: Remove the support and you can use the picarail

comments.text:
Pretty legit, but it has a few issues.
1) The right side rails hit the hopper so you cant actually fit this shroud on the marker. I had to take a Dremel to the finished part and remove about a half inch of the rail from the back.
2) The top of the lower pin hits the small lip under the left rail. I had to mortis out a circle of that lip so that the pin would fit.
3) The upper pin hole wont line up because the very top of the marker isn't flat. It kind of angles out slightly. That's hard to explain, but either way all I had to do was sand off a bit at the rear of the print. Only a few mm.

I have been experimenting with RAMPS 1.4 and Bowden extruding. One thing I needed was a stand-alone way to connect and test the setup without changing my printer.
So I created this design this weekend.
The top support mounts loosely and can be easily added or removed.

Update July 20, 2015:
I just realized that I had inserted the wrong file. You should see a new file test stand base, this is the correct file. I apologize to anyone who may have downloaded this project and ask that you remove the waveshare one, if you don't need it :-), and replace it with the new file.

Note: The extruder in the background is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:589149. (giving credit where credit is due)

Print the base and support.
mount two 8 mm rods on the base and them add the support bar to the top.
Optionally, you could print two 8 mm rods of the desired length.

This is a replacement wheel for the table belonging to a vintage, pedal-powered Husqvarna sewing machine. The measurements are NOT accurate as the old wheel was pretty much destroyed, and I didn't want to touch the one that was still OK. It's FUNCTIONALLY the same, but is not a 'pattern perfect' match. This is not generally suited for 3D printing, unless you have a printer that can print really solid objects. Instead, it should be cut out of HDPE or similar materials using a CnC mill.
Uploaded mostly to demonstrate the 'Rotate Extrude' function in OpenSCAD.

Coupling to connect M8 threaded rod leadscrew to 5mm stepper motor shaft. (It seems Thingiverse lost the list of materials)
List of materials:
  • 1-2cm of flexible tubing e.g. 4x6 or 4x7mm
  • M8 coupling nut
  • M8 nut for contra

• slide the tubing on 5mm motor shaft
  • thread one nut (or better yet, a coupling nut) onto the top of the tubing so that half of the nut is above the shaft
  • thread another nut onto the threaded rod
  • screw the rod onto the nut on the motor
  • tighten the rod against motor shaft (but not too tight)
  • tighten the nuts against each other
    • I used coupling nut on the picture for better grip, but it seems to work with regular nut as well. I don't see a reason why this shouldn't work for 5/16" threaded rod as well.

comments.text:
I've used this setup on both 3DP's & CNC routers for the past 10 years, never had a failure. I usualy solder or pin the coupler to the threaded rod depending on the size, insert the tubing, then press fit the nema shaft. A little spit helps... ;)
I've use this on nema24's with a 1/2" thread on my drillpress XY table, & it's worked perfectly.
Tip: Use stainless threaded rod & nuts. It's a few extra bucks, but well worth it. Threaded is slower than ACME due to the higher pitch, but it can mean better micro-stepping on a tightly tuned machine, which equals better layers.
Spinning the rod in a drill & knocking the sharp edge off the threads with medium grit sandpaper will make it run much smoother.
Depending on use, I change out the tubing about once a year when I do maintenance.

Anatomical heart sculpted in ZBrush. I made this accurate to the best of my ability but obviously the interior is hollow unlike a professional medical heart model.

I originally sculpted this at life size, but scaled it down by about 25% to save money on material costs. The pictures you see are the Frosted Ultra Detail via Shapeways (http://shpws.me/IF2n), which gives it a nice transparency affect. I'm not sure how this would come out a FDM printer but I'd love to see someone give it a shot!
I made this via Shapeways in the Frosted Ultra Detail material. No guarantees about how an FDM printer might deal with this. The thinnest wall is .8mm I believe.

Hello! I'm a student at the University of Utah and for one of my classes I will be putting on an exhibit at my school about race and genetics. In our exhibit we talk about how race is a social construct. In our display we wanted to show this point artistically by having the same 3-D heart printed four times and placed on display side by side and saying "this is a black heart, this is a white heart..." and ect demonstrating that were all human and race is only skin deep. I would like permission to use your 3-D heart in our exhibit. Its a free exhibit so no money will be profited from your 3D heart and it will not be sold, it will be used for display purposes only. And if you like I can send you pictures of the display using your 3D model in our exhibit when its done.
Thanks Melanie Prettyman.

Although the dime barge video shows it holding $15 dollars, I've been able to load $20 dollars in it before.

I learned how to use Autodesk 123D Design. I am a sophomore Mechanical Engineering student at the University of North Florida in Jacksonville, FL. I just started working for a friend who runs a non-profit company called Renaissance Jax. The goal of Renaissance Jax is to build hundreds of robotics teams around north Florida and after, across the U.S. We want to build an army of STEM students and in doing so we are on our way to see thousands of middle and high school students in just the next Fall and Spring. The company has a Robo 3D printer but would like to have a MakerBot as well due to its superiority. We use 3D printers for all the kids to prototype ideas for their robots and get excited about STEM. This would bring press from all over and get the word out for the MakerBot Replicator Desktop 3D Printer. Goodluck to all the challengers and happy hunting for the judges.

Autodesk 123D Design
Autodesk inventor professional
(Both Free!!)
Just add tea leaves, close it and stick it into your cup

Print it in ABS! (PLA will bend with the hot water)

0% infill
No support
1,2mm wall thickness
0,5mm top/bottom thickness

I use CURA.

I don't think you need a hot bed for this print, I use one but there's literally no bending, and with any other ABS print, I get bending, even with the hot bed

title: GoPro Swivel Mount w. wingnut (Large Base)

description.text:
Rotate your GoPro by 360° on the Go...
Including 2 different tops. One for standard GoPro quick release clip. Recommend this rather than the fork/screw attachement.

NEW: Tripod legs with 10mm threading for quick adjustment
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:986755

Printed on an XYZ Da Vinci, Black ABS, 50% infill, layer height 0,2 with supports (on the top mount). Print time roughly 8 hours in total. High infill or solid recommended on the top part.

15/08/27:
Tripod legs added

Current Specifications (15/07/20) :
120x120mm baseplate, 5,5mm diameter rope bore holes (corners), 4x45mm strap grooves, 65mm cylindrical top. M6 bore hole for bolt & wingnut. Total height: around 55mm.
+-65° Tilt, 360° Turn. Dimensions corrected and improved, parts merged.

Changelog:

150722/5:15 GMT: GoPromount swiveltop (04) altered; length of extrusions decreased by 1,5mm to now 24mm; height of top base decreased by 1,5mm to save material, as weak spot was found to be the mounting points for gopro mount itself. Do not pull on it accidentally while getting into a canoe and slipping :P hence recommendation of solid or 90% infill in the top part (03/04) of the swivelmount.

150721/21:15 GMT: Alternate swiveltop added with GoPro-mount grooves, allows more stability and increased tilt angle, eg. when using vertically.

150720/03:55 GMT: Parts 02+03 melded to one, as their seperation didn't make sense and was result of developement. The tines of the mount part again made thinner in all directions, increased radii, and compared with a CAD model from Grabcad.

150719/21:08 GMT: THIS VERSION HAS BEEN UPDATED!!! Previous part 03 did NOT FIT!

Rotate your GoPro by 360° on the Go... large base with various fixing/attachement points for ropes, ties etc..

Bill of Materials:

1x M6x12 screw (DIN 6921)
1x M6 Wingnut (DIN 315) max. height of wings around 12-13 mm (!)

  • for part 03 (using the swiveltop and direct go pro attachment)
    1x standard M6 Nut
    1x GoPro Screw

optional:
1x Washer M6 DIN 125

Previously printed with 50% infill in the Base plate. Recommendation to print the top swivel (03, 04) using at least 90% infill. (!)

author: slavikk

description.text:
This flashlight I have been using about 3 months ago, I was quite happy with the result although a little difficult to install components. The idea comes from here: http://www.instructables.com/id/LED-Torch-2, there are some components that I replace it with what I have.

Electronic components that I use is:

  1. 8 mm straw hat LED
  2. 6.8Ohm Resistor 5%
  3. Diode IN 4007
  4. Push Button Switch(http://www.ebay.com/itm/10x-Red-Push-Button-Switch-6-Pins-Latching-DPDT-Tact-Tactile-Self-locking-DPDT-/380810457498)
    5.DC power jack (http://www.p-wholesale.com/upimg/5/121a2/dc-power-jack-570.jpg)
  5. Battery 4V 1200mA
  6. 3mm allen socket bolt with 10mm long, 2 pieces.
  7. 3mm hex screw nut, 2 pieces.

I also attach a new diagram, this flashlight can light up more than 8 hours. Charging the battery using an adapter 5V 1A for 1.5 hours.

Print all with high-layer 0.3 mm except LEDflahlight -_ o_ring.STL uses 0.2 mm, and all using the brim 2 mm, without support, infill 100%.

Clean all brim using scissors, attach all components to the component holder, and this is the hardest part. Make the hole about 4 mm at the bottom of the lid, if the battery is removed you can push it using the tip of a screwdriver. After that plug and tighten the two nuts and bolts.

Spray paint with the black base two or three layers of paint, drying each coat of paint about 10 minutes, and the final layer is the chrome-colored with the same number of paint layers as before. Wait for one day so that the paint is completely dry.

May differ from the paint you have, do not often touch the chrome paint because it will change color to gray.
This object is based on a rubber band in the shape of an animal.

Workflow: Image (jpg) > Inkscape (svg) > Blender (stl) > Cura (gcode).

I've printed it double the size of the model (200 mm high and 3mm thick) with three perimeters (1.2mm), 1mm top and bottom layers, and 25% infill.

remixed_from.author: msurguy
remixed_from.title: Shorter Printrbot Plus LC Filament guide

title: Printrbot Plus LC double bearing filament guide

description.text:
You will need two M8 screews and two 608 bearings. The guide is designed to sit loosely on the axle so it can move when it needs to.
This means, the filament needs to be positioned lower than the guide, or it may come off. (See image of my setup in the Gallery)

I have used two filament guides before, one that was fully printed and which got eaten away by the rougher filaments, another one - with one bearing which tended to make quite some noise when the filament switched from one side to another.

Open Scad file is attached so you can adjust the bottom hole for a tighter fit.

helper_tabs = 1

Parts designed to use multiple lengths of 1/2 inch Schedule 40 PVC pipe for greater strength and rigidity.
.
Also may be used with wooden dowels (of appropriate size) if the use of PVC offends your sensibilities.

ABS recommended; scale to fit the PVC pipe available in your area.
.
Once parts are screwed into the pipes the objects are surprisingly strong. Could be useful for creating machine mock-ups before committing to cut aluminum extrusion.
.
Sample images show painted parts to provide better contrast (I used natural ABS which didn't photograph well).
.
The black part is from the original PVC pipe construction set.
.
Designed with TinkerCad.

UPDATE: 21-Jul-15: A few parts require supports; be very careful...there are many pointy bits and you will bleed.
.
A ratchet-style PVC pipe cutter is a good investment if you like clean cuts on the pipe. A chamfer on the ends will allow easier assembly.
.
Because of layer orientation, some parts may separate if the fit is too snug. Sandpaper is your friend.
.
Updated files with simpler screw locations will be forthcoming.

UPDATE 31-Jul-15: The parts are attached with small sheet metal screws; I drilled 2mm pilot holes for them.
.
UPDATE 10-Aug-15: Added part ("T-Bone") to allow simple t-junction.

title: K40 Chinese CO2 Laser Exhaust Adapter Plate

description.text:
I wanted better exhaust extraction for my K40 Laser cutter/engraver.
The original fume blower that came with it wasn't doing a good job especially with Plexiglass/Acrylic, so an upgrade was due.

I got this inline-blower from Amazon
http://amzn.com/B005KMOJPK

A Flex duct-hose, and a 3"-4" adapter from Menard's.

I have attached a .PLT file ready for cutting. Which I modified a little to
fit my setup.

And to give credit where credit is due, this box is not my design, it is the fine work of cnczone.com member "slow_rider"
http://www.cnczone.com/forums/general-laser-engraving-cutting-machine-discussion/264830-new-diy-exhaust-k40-co2-laser-cutter.html

original DXF files are located there.

Enjoy...

F.K

P.S, Please express yourself, collect, like, download and comment.

Pretty dead simple!
Cut the parts, assemble them as shown. They usually go in without a problem and it is pretty straight forward.

I used hot-glue (or if you have more time, silicon sealant is better) to
seal the insides and assemble it all together.

Then add the 3"-to-4" adapter (make sure it fits snugly before gluing the box together to avoid excessive pressure to the box) and seal it off around for good measure.

I also added door-trip insulation to the box to get a good tight fit.

Hook up your inline blower in a way that suits your setup/environment and you are good to go.

Happy laser cutting.

description.text:
I fly my ZMR like I stole it, this means i'm not afraid to crash it, that said I crash quite a bit trying to see what I can squeeze the quad through =). At first I made these with a 10 degree angle to increase forward speed but found that they protected the the motors so well that we now put them on all our quads! Pictures show 2204 sized motors and they have been in many many crashes and are still in perfect condition. (motors in picture were flown for a while without these but have sustained no damage since) These have been tested by me and by Team High Society plus my local quad club with the same results.

Video of me flying with these: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9jqw-2g81pA

Print in either ABS or PLA with 90% infill and .2 layer height.

The carbon fiber ZMR frame has 3mm arms, with two (2) on each arm use M3x12mm bolts with washer to hold the motors.

Enjoy!

title: Desiccant Box with Slotted Snap on Lid, 80mm long

description.text:
This is a resized version of micromet's excellent Desiccant Box with Slotted Snap-on Lid

The box fits inside Perception Engineering's Filament Safe. The outer length of the lid is about 85mm, which fits the 90mm wide stalls.

Print the box in a clear material and use color indicating silica gel beads. This makes it easy to tell when the desiccant is saturated. The box prints well with clear Taulman T-Glase.

I printed the box with clear Taulman T-Glase](http://taulman3d.com/t-glase-features.html) using a 0.35mm nozzle and 0.325mm layer height. I used a PEI build plate at 60C. The parts adhered well, without brim or special bed preparation.

author: scarpi

description.text: A Sandisk holder with three different slots to put SD cards in on the top.  It is customized on both sides with an extruded area that has my name on one side and my favorite sports team on the other.  It then goes outward into a wide base to support the structure.  Made with pink plastic on the thing-o-matic makerbot.

Started with a trapezoid base, and made a rectangular body on top of it.  Created another rectangular body on top of that and made three rectangular extrusions into it.  Lastly I added in embosses, chamfered, and made fillets to the bases.
Cupcake with frosting and a heart on top. There is space inside for a small object.

Print the top, frosting, and heart at 0.2mm layer height. The frosting and top will require supports. Assemble and glue together. I used superglue on PLA - takes a while, but after drying overnight, it holds well.

Print the wrapper at 0.3mm layer height, no supports.

comments.text: It took about 7 hours on a PrintrBot Simple Metal with the default speed.

remixed_from.title: Kossel Mini 800 Delta 3D Printer (Magnetic Joints System)

description.text:
Same as the original Kossel Mini 800 effector, but modified to fit the E3D V6 hot end.

The Diameter of the fixing hole was increased to 16.2mm (giving it 0.2mm tolerance), and the depth was decreased to 3.8mm (with no tolerance, to ensure a tight fit when clamping).

Recommend using a hard plastic like ABS, but also one that doesn't warp. My test print was done in solid Nylon 645 and flexes slightly.

Relevant parts you may also need:

6 x N52 Strong Round Magnets (∅12 x 4mm)
6 x ∅10 M4 Threaded Ball Rod Ends
6 x M4x20mm Grub Set Screw
6 x ∅6x4mm L200mm Carbon Fiber Tube Rods

You can find the majority of these items on this ebay store page:
http://stores.ebay.com/hksupport/Rostock-Kossel-Delta-/_i.html?_fsub=6333435016

author: krofinski

title: Treble Hook Guard for Fishing Rod

description.text:
-= This is a work in progress =-

This thing is perfect for fishermen on the go!

Most of the time when I go on a fishing trip, I just want to throw my gear in the car, and head out for the fishing spots. Sometimes I just make a few casts at one place and then head for the next. I throw my rod, with lure and everything in the backseat of the car and heads on. Then, when I reach my next fishing spot and grabs my gear... the lure is often attached to the interior of the car...

With this treble hook holder, you can your attach your lures or spinner baits (with hook size 4-6) easily on you fishing rod!

This is a One-size fits most...
it fit rods with diameter 6.5 - 9 mm.

Note that It might be a little tricky to attach on the rod the first time after printing since it's a close fit. But once you get it on your rod it should stick rather well.

Note:
I'm still working on the holder part for the rod, so If you have any tips or suggestions for improvement don't be afraid to give me a comment!
printed with a 0.35 mm nozzle, no support. 0.2 or 0,1 layer hight

author: Ekdahl

description.text:
June 2017:
News!!!
The rudder assembly has been reworked to allow for a change in the pitch angle. I mounted to servos and mix them (V-tail program on the transmitter). You need two 624ZZ 4mm x 13mm x 5mm ball bearing.
I added a new set of back foils (symmetrical) as well.
The boat is much more stable now!
I thing that if you don't want to add the relative complexity of a mixing servos, it should work just by setting up the proper angle and fasten it in place.

Thanks for your comments and I hope that you guys will build it, it's a great project!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FkvLngxzD9I
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wZ5s8Pop9LE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rXsFfcyyV-E

July 26th 2015: This is my latest attempt of a RC hydrofoil.

The profile is a Naca 63-412 (both front and back foils). The back foil has a 5deg dihedral for lateral stability. It's in two parts, glued together, in order to print the part without support.

The foiler is actually flying but on a very narrow speed range. Enough to make it lift itself and not too fast otherwise the prop is reaching the surface and starts to cavitate.

I would really appreciate any suggestion to improve it.

As mentioned previously, I’m working on a new hull, in four parts of max 15 cm so it would be printable on a variety of printers. Keep you posted.

Penny Express – Not 1898 pennies, but just one riding in style!

This is my entry to the MakeItFloat challenge.

I always wanted to make a RC hydrofoil, so what a great opportunity.

This is my first real project with 123D Design and 3d printing and I can tell you that I learned a lot.

This boat can theoretically carry 1’898 pennies, but I decided that only one would ride, so I had to find a very special place.

After 6 weeks of endless nights and weekends, about 100 hours of total printing time three prototypes and almost 40 iterations, what I expected to be a simple project finally started to lift up two days ago (video here; https://youtu.be/DgALh0y2N18).

I tried every thing that I can think of; changing the foil profile, size, angle without much success. I truly experimented Thomas Edison quote: “I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work.”

I wanted to do a simple boat, with an air propeller as propulsion with basic RC equipment, but my first prototypes acted more like fast diving submarines that flying boats. They were too heavy, too unstable and too small. I finally went for a more conventional marine setup. The hardware is easily available in any boat hobby shops.

In my latest prototype I reduced the thickness of the hull from 3mm to 1,6mm and almost double the overall size. It looks great and flies well.

This model is easily modifiable; the foils just interlock in the hull and can easily be removed and changed. There are 15 parts altogether and they can be printed without rafters or supports (PLA) in any printer that can print in a volume of 18cm x 18cm x 18cm. I will update the files to be printable on a 15cm height printer.

The hull of the latest version is in three parts that are glued together using 5 minutes epoxy. The front foil is in four parts allowing to print a large foil (modified Naca 4412-33 profile).

There are almost no RC hydrofoil models or plans available and very limited info on them, so I hope that this project will serve as a base for any one interested in pushing it further.

Thanks’ a million for the learning experience and having make an old dream come true!

Printing tips:
I printed all parts in PLA with a fill density of 20%.
The hull parts are all printed in a “vase” configuration.
The back hull is printed back down.
The middle part front down, and the front part back down.
The back foil has a flat bottom so it prints in one piece (very cool looking part ;-)
The front foil is printed in four parts, glued together with epoxy in the middle of the profile. I sanded the foil to have a better penetration.
The two front panels are glued in place with silicon once the components are in place. The back panel is just taped on with duct tape (the only one that I can find that actually stick to the PLA). This is not satisfying, suggestions are welcome!
The foils (front and back are just tacked glued in place with a little bit of silicon. Very easy to get out if needed.
The motor mount was design to fit a 960Kv 480 brushless outrunner motor. I will update it to a more generic support in the near future.

Design considerations:
The actual front foils are 4412-33 scaled down in thickness to 75% with a 6 deg positive angle. They are too powerful for the light wait of the boat using a 1800 mA 3S battery. I will try a dipper V angle with a 5 deg angle next. The front foils are inserted in to Dagger board housing with easy dimensions, so feel free to experiment and please let me know if you are making progress.

In this configuration, the boat has a very narrow speed range. I hope that the new foils will correct that.

Please let me know if you need more info.

author: Thunter124

title: CP5S - articulating LED work light system

description.text:
This is a concept for jointed system that utilizes cpvc pipe. This was my first design, I've wanted a nice LED work light setup for my desk, I haven't printed any of this yet, but I'll do that later today and update for the tolerances of my machine.

CP5S is my working title for this series, "CP" stands for "cpvc pipe", "5" for ".5in size" and the "S" is for "system". Sorta dumb But hey, I had to call it something

I inteded for this to be printed with E3D volcano .6mm nozzles. Your tolerances may be different, if anybody wants me to I can make another set at exact sizes to be drilled out. Using .36mm layer heights turns good results. base 6 will need a little bit of bridging, so be ready for that, otherwise the rest of it should be pretty easy to print.

The Lighting uses 3Watt LED modules from Amazon. They need heat sinks!! They will quickly burn themselves out if you just run them at their max brightness constantly. I'll, upload a picture of heat sink once I'm done with it. For now I'm using an adjustable step-down buck converter to dial in the voltage, probably should use a constant current driver but that's spendy. with 4 LED's you may be able to get away with them in series on a 12v power supply. You should use a thicker guage wire so that the lights can hang be supported by it at the end. I'm using a wire with 2 wires wrapped in it (not sure what its called) its a fairly thick guage though, should be plenty to support the heat sink, diffuser, and LED.

The CPVC pipe is nice for this because you can run the wiring through the pipe to clean up the look of the final product. I haven't decided how I'm going to finish this product yet, probably airbrush it black or silver or something.

title: Belt Holder for the printing bed (Y axis) of a PRUSA I3

description.text:
This is a Belt Holder for the Y axis of the Sunhokey PRUSA I3.

I changed the original printing bed (which was too soft because made in acrylic on the Sunhokey's kit, and leading to permanent needs of bed leveling) by a MK2 aircraft aluminium bed (very rigid). With the new printing bed, there is the need to drill the holes in proper place for the linear ball bearings (take the position of them on the old acrylic printing bed), and also there is a need for a new belt holder.

This auto locking system of the belt is derived from the Belt Clip I recently published. It do not take any tool to install the belt, because the belt is natively maintained in a "self-locking" position by this Belt Holder. Just insert the belt inside the groove and it's done !

The SKETCHUP file is attached in case of need of adaptation.

This Belt Holder have been created as a quite universal one for this kind of printers, so the base is larger than needed in case other holes reveal to be necessary for some other printer. Hence, it should fit with any other printing beds of the same category of printers.

For a better quality of the printing of this device, it is in 2 parts which just has to be assembled by a M3 bolt and nut.

(I would suggest to not modify the other parts of the object, except in case you would completely draw it again)
Also, note that this object can be used in horizontal or vertical position, in this last case the base just having to be enlarged in order to give more space to the bolts and nuts. I've just attached an extended version to the files for this.

The Water Spyder is a Holonomic Paddleboat proof of concept prototype. Holonomic drive systems give vehicles the ability to move in any direction. Holonomic drives have been used on land vehicles but never on an aquatic vehicle. This gives a boat the ability to manuver in very tight spaces and avoid collisions that are encountered while docking. It also puts a modern twist on the classic Paddleboats from the days of Mark Twain.
Video at: https://youtu.be/uarlV3mlUmE

Here are the parts that you will need to construct the water spyder:
1 Main Hull
1 Hull Cap
1 Hull Bottom
4 Motor Housings
4 Motor housing caps
4 Paddlewheels
Print These items at 50% infill or less to make the craft more buoyant

1 Switch
6 Jumper Cables
1 9 volt battery
1 9 volt battery snap
1 mini breadboard
24 4mm thread 5mm long screws.

Assembly:
1 Attach the Hull Bottom and Main Hull with Glue and sealant so it is water tight.
2 While the hull dries, solder Jumper cables to 4 hobby DC motors and solder the battery snap inline with the switch.
3 Place each motor inside a Motor
Housing and glue securely.
4 Screw a moto housing cap onto each motor houing the seal using a sealant.
5 Slide each motor housing into the main hull.
6 Wire the balltery leads thorught the switch and connect to a breadboard to create a power strip.
7 Plug the leads from the motors into the breadboard to power the motors.
8 Attach the paddlewheels onto the motor shafts it should pop on.
9 Switch the polarities of the motors to make the motors spin in the desired direction. (You can also use an ardunino and an h bridge to control the motors)
10 Glue the Switch into the cap and screw the cap onto the Hull.

The rods in it are either 48mm or 51mm apart (there are two variants), along the LONG sides of the effector, judging by the photos. Or are you saying something about an issue other than the spacing between the rods/balls?
comments.author: wittmason

comments.text: I was looking over this file for a Kossel XL I'm building from scratch, but I need to modify its dimensions slightly to match other components I'm considering. Of most relevance, I'm thinking of using https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2012132 as an effector, which is available with 48mm or 51mm inter-ball spacing for its magnetic arms. Looking over the self_locking_carriage-v2.scad file, it appears that there are two variables that might be relevant: ballStudDistance (set to 24.2) sets the distance from the centerline of each of the holes into which the ball studs are to be mounted; and rodSeparation (set to 49) is the distance between the posts in which those ball studs are set. Given what these variables control, I'd expect ballStudDistance to be exactly half of rodSeparation, but that's not the case in this carriage. Why is that? (I note that the v1 design you used as a base lacks the ballStudDistance variable entirely, since it lacks a hole and instead relies on a ball glued into a dimple in the part.) I've measured the virtual distance between the stud-mounting holes in the generated .stl file and in the matching holes in the effector I want to use in MeshLab, and I get distances of about 48.4 to 48.6mm from your carriage vs. 48mm from the effector, so the more important value seems to be ballStudDistance. I've tried tweaking this value, and it then matches that of the effector model much more closely. I'm new to delta printers, but my understanding is that the rods must be exactly parallel, so the stud distances must match precisely on the effector and the carriage. (If this is incorrect, please do correct me!)
comments.author: rodsmith

title: PRUSA I3 - Muffler for the fan of the Power Supply

description.text:
This is a muffler for a drastic reduction of the noise of the fan of the Power Supply of a PRUSA I3 by Sunhokey.

This muffler is quite big because it should not reduce the air flow, but only reduce the noise of the small fan of the Power Supply which turns quite fast and is very noisy when a printing job is under process.

It revealed to be able to reduce by 2/3 the noise of the Power Supply.

The SKETCHUP file is attached.

After printing teh complete object, the 4 legs was badly done (not yet an air fan to cool down the object), then I just cutted them off, and I used a band of tape on the top to ensure the muffler will not fall by itself.

Note that in complement, I added some foam between the Power Supply and the frame of the printer, on the front side only. It had its effect too. Be careful to not close any of the air vents, and to let all of them get a direct access to the air in the room (I left the back completely open between the PS and the frame)

VERY IMPORTANT. Also note that the PS shall NOT be installed as Sunhokey indicates, because the fact the PS is directly along the frame closes too many air vents, and this very quickly creates a very bad hot smell, typically announcing the overheat and the very next burn of the PS. Instead of their preconisations, I replaced the bolts which maintain the PS on the frame by longer ones which leaves a sufficient gap for the air to flow freely. Have a look at the photos. Since, there is no problem.

author: sanitrad

description.text:
The idea:
for the science challenge I wanted to design something that demonstrates the principle of buoyancy, displacement and density. Density is calculated by dividing mass by volume so both have to be measured. Volume is measured by the displacement of water in a container and mass by means of buoyancy. Additionally I wanted to show the comparison between to objects with different densities but same mass in the way Archimedes did it.

The design:
-measure volume:
A cylinder is filled about half with water and the level marked. Then coins are tossed in and the water rises.
The difference in height equals to the volume of the coins divided by the surface area of the water.
If the surface area is 1000mm^2, the water will rise 1mm for every cm^3 of coin volume. To get this area the radius of the cylinder has to be the square root of 1000mm^2/pi = 17.84mm.
-measure weight:
the cylinder has an outside radius of 25.23mm and an area of 2000mm^2 so it will sink 1mm for every 2g. This can be measured with the outer part that floats.
-compare density
on each side of the scale the same amount of weight is placed but on one side the material is denser than on the other. Then the scale is immersed in water where the less dense material displaces more water and this side of the scale rises.

The test:
for testing I used 50c coins which weigh 7.8g and have a density of 8.54 g/cm^3 and a silver coin which weighs an ounce (31.1g) and has a density of 10.49 g/cm^3.

text = Avila

This curiously shaped device prevents hard drops of the Z stage on the MakerGear M2 when the motors are turned off and disengage. It is designed to have enough flexibility to gently slow the Z stage to a halt, but not prevent the Z stage from being pushed all the way to its maximum extent if needed. It slips over the M2's frame base and snaps into place. It is designed to be printed in PETg, which has the right amount of strength and flexibility for the spring's thickness, width, and curvature as designed.

The original version worked but was incorrectly sized, and so has been deprecated and removed. There are now three versions: springcurve2, springcurve3, and springcurve4. Springcurve2 installs with the curve pointing toward the back; in this position the curve must be made narrower and is therefore stiffer. It has not been tested. Springcurve3 is a re-creation of Michael Hunter's Z axis return spring (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:615104), but with the ability to clip onto the frame base like the other springcurve models. I find that it exceeds the strain limit of the plastic and tends to permanently deform it. Springcurve4 installs with the curve pointing toward the front. It is a direct derivative of the original springcurve model, but correctly sized, and the front of the base conveniently snaps into place. This one has been installed and tested, and is the recommended model to use.

Inspired by Michael Hunter's Z axis return spring (thing 61504).

The model "springcurve4" has been tested and is the recommended model to print and install.

Use PETg filament, which is what this is designed for. ABS probably works about as well. PLA is too rigid/brittle for the application.

Install springcurve4 with the end of the curve facing forward on the M2. The curve should meet the base just forward of the wiring harness. With the motors disengaged, let the Z stage drop from the height of the extruders. The springcurve should stop the base gently. It should be possible to continue to crank the Z stage down with minimal force; this should not cause the springcurve to permanently deform.

comments.text: When my printer homes this one just snaps. I guess I should modify the end_code.g so the z-drive doesnt place the printbed to the lowest possible position.
comments.author: Kulturfolger

comments.text: Yes, Jin is right.  This is designed for the home Z position on top, which is what I have.  I thought that it would be possible to force the spring all the way to the bottom without snapping, though, but I have several modifications on my printer which restrict the full height by a bit, so I can't actually test that proposition.  What type of filament did you print it with?  PETg has the highest strength for the amount it can flex.  PLA would definitely snap.  I suggested that ABS would probably work, but I don't have any ABS filament so that's another untested theory.
comments.author: Kulturfolger

comments.text: New M2s home to the bottom. Older ones home to the top.
comments.author: Kulturfolger

comments.text: The newest version is "springcurve4" and I am satisfied with its position, size, and performance.  Note that I have reversed its position front to back compared with the original version (which I have removed;  version springcurve2 is similar to the original).
comments.author: TimEdwards

comments.text: What scale is it modeled in?
comments.author: jsc

comments.text: It's in millimeters.  The total length of the slot on the base is 175mm, which is what my M2 frame measures front to back.  The top part of the curve is a bit too far to the back, and should be centered.  That's why this is currently marked as a "thing in progress".  I was going to run a few iterations before going public, but the first cut had the right amount of flex to it, so I went ahead and posted it.  I think it could also improve by being designed to fit over the holes in the base plate where the feet of the M2 are screwed in.  That would allow the spring to be firmly bolted down, while postioning it under the main arm of the Z stage.
comments.author: jsc

comments.text: The bounding dimensions appear to be 186x136, is that right? It seems overlarge. What do you do about the electronics box, or have you moved that? Can you post a photo of it in place?
comments.author: TimEdwards

comments.text: Okay, photo added.  It is a bit over-large, intentionally, although it's just a lot of guesswork as to how much it will bend vs. how thick it needs to be to withstand the weight of the Z stage without snapping in half.  As I said before, my original intention was to run a few iterations of this to see how it works at different sizes, thickness, curvature, position, etc.  I was actually pretty surprised that it worked more or less exactly as planned with these dimensions, so I went ahead and posted it.  You can wait for the 2.0 version.  : )

description.text:
If you want to learn how to play the Great Highland Bagpipes or you want to print yourself a new Practice Chanter, this is your THING!

This Practice Chanter has a surprisingly great sound!

I will try to build a printable reed so you don't have to buy one :)

Here is the Chanter in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BwPB0PRyYNE

Or read the article on 3dprint.com:
http://3dprint.com/83196/3d-printed-practice-chanter/

Layer: 0.2mm or less
Supports: on
Infill: 30-40%

You will need two 18x2mm O-Rings...
The parts are glued together except the big one.

title: Earthing - Grounding plugs for diam 4 mm Red Round Connector

description.text:
Conductive and flexible plugs to get earthing/grounding for ESD protection etc, in this case using my filament PI-ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black.

Could perhaps be used for:
¤ESD-protection (make sure to use 1MOhm, use extra resistor, that is what is used in the industry)
¤Earthing: http://www.earthinginstitute.net/ (better to use a wire to the actual ground outdoors!)

In my case I measured aprox 1KOhm resistance through the type F plug (Schuko) http://www.worldstandards.eu/electricity/plugs-and-sockets/f/ at:
¤Temp: 230 deg C
¤Speed: 3600 mm/min
¤0.7mm nozzle
¤Layers: 0.2mm
¤Top layers: 8
¤Bottom layers: 7
¤Shells: 2

Plug Type B: http://www.worldstandards.eu/electricity/plugs-and-sockets/ab/

Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this:

This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design:

•The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/84NhoZGbuiS

Summer holidays 2014 I walked to the Berlin waters along (Berlin = capital of Germany) to go on vacation. I saw many speedboats and many houseboats. They made me to build one for me when I am older. Saturday, 20 June 2015 I have searched the internet for 3D printers and 3D modelling and came to the Thingiverse website. After a few minutes I found the S.T.E.A.M. Challenges. It didn´t need much time to choose the #MakeItFloat Challenge and sad: “I can build a houseboat!” After five afternoons of work (in the morning I go to school of course) I had a model of a houseboat. But I haven´t got a 3D printer. So I have searched the internet for 3D Hubs or Makerspaces. I have found one in Dresden: the Makerspace in the Saxon State Library and University Library Dresden. Next day I went there and they said: “We will print your model but it will take some time.” Three weeks I was very exiting whether all details are printable. After these weeks of waiting the print of the model of my houseboat finished but there was one week left to change things before uploading the model. I have changed some things but there wasn´t time left for a second print in the Makerspace Dresden.
I have chosen Autodesk Inventor Professional 2014 Student Version (Student, because I am fifteen now) to design my houseboat. I have inspired me from summer 2014. I have had fun to design and I am happy with the result. My houseboat is much decorated in detail and it is a one thing print. So I have described all rooms and the ground plans of the two floors. This you can see in some uploaded pictures.
I have had fun to design and describe all rooms. So if you find “I must print it” please choose the smallest layer high to print (at least 0,1 mm layer height for all details). I have uploaded a short film too. Check the link for watching.
URL film: http://youtu.be/KG7uafrgox0

Attention: The .STL - file is version 1.1 of my model. Model version 1.0 you can see in the film and in the featured picture because there wasn´t time to print version 1.1. Reasons see description.

I had to make new ones for my diy prusa. Is printed with ABS at 0.3 layer and 20% infill, is much better than those i had.

Is ok but maybe i make some changes not for usabillity as for the look.

20% Infill
0.3 Layer
Cura slicer

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5eTMlasSkes

This is one try of text in spherical coodinate.

Many people makes flat text, and calls it as 3D text. But it is not true 3D but only 2.1D or 2.5D.

This time I also made assembling jig.

North and south parts are connected by 8 pins, so it is easy to take apart to change colors.

I am using DaVinci 1.0 3D printer by XYZ printing.

Layer pitch is 0.2mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness.

No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT).

320 minutes to print. 30 minutes for shaping, constructing and sanding.
1$ for ABS.

Other parts.
8 pins (ø3*10, SUS)

How to use pins?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNg1lNYXcFk

In case of traditional machining, making accurate pin-holes on object is not so easy thing,
especially if the object is small, has irregular shape or the pin-hole is angled.
Because it needs additional assembling jigs to fix.

However, in case of 3D printing, it is pretty easy.
It does not need any other cost, except adding holes in 3D data.

The metal pins are enough accurate, so you can make both type of holes lock and roose easily.
Also it is much more strong than 3D printing materials, so you can make thin strut or axle.
Also it is enough cheap so you can bury under objects, or glue it.

Of course you can use screws. Actually screws are more usual in real world.
However you have to tap holes, you can not make loose screw or you can not joint objects face by face because it needs driver.

note. You need "reamer" and "drill chuck" to adjust holes.

title: My entry for the make it float challenge. #MakeItFloat !

description.text:
Version one (green)
Version two (gold)

This is my entry for the make it float challenge. My thought behind this challenge was to draw the boat like they are in real life, like a scale model.

I started off way to ambitious, my first boat (green) had room for 120 2 euro coins, it immediately sank. It floats very well on its own , but it will only hold up to 20 2 euro coins (170) grams. The boat itself wheighs 70 grams. I drew a fancy top cover to cover the coins and to make it look like a real boat. Unfortunately, due to a lack of time (very busy studying and working) I didn't have the time to print it.

For the second prototype I took a better look at the huge freighter ships. The hull looks much more like the actual real life ships. It floats very well on its own, and this second version can hold up to 40 coins (340 grams). The boat itself wheighs 105 grams.

I can conclude that this was a significant progress , I was able to double the amount of weight it can carry, and it still looks like a regular real life size ship.

If I had more time I would have continued this process to optimize the ship and to make it carry as mucht as possible, while still looking like a real ship.

Both the hull files are printable on their own, I printed them with layer thickness 0.2. Version one took 5 hours and 39 minutes, version two took 6 hours and 27 minutes.

Due to a bad vertical shell slicer setting on the first boat, I had to seal the the hull with glue to make it watertight.

The second version looks a bit wrinkled on the back end, that's because of the overhang it had to print. It still is watertight though.

It was a total pleasure to work on this project, thank you Makerbot and Thingiverse for giving us the opportunity to be a part of this challenge!

author: Bjornnijen

description.text:
I couldn't find a good dock for my apple watch, so I decided to build one that doesn't fall over when docking.

Tested with:
Milanese loop (best fit)
Link band (very good fit)
Sports band (good fit)

Features:

  1. Holds the charger and cable firmly but yet easily removable.
  2. Holds the watch band with minimal slop
  3. Dockable in BOTH orientations!
  4. Supports BOTH 38mm and 42mm. (thanks dssguy1 for testing the 38mm for me)
  5. Simple, quick way to charge without having to fool around with the charger.
  6. Include solid works files for your editing pleasure.

Hope you enjoy!

Tested with makerbot 2 with 0.3 mm layer height. All other settings default.
print both base and holder, assemble, and enjoy!

Note: there are two holders for the different watch sizes but the base is the same.

description.text:
This is a valve block with integrated passively controlled valves that can be printed in one piece. The valves have a clearence of 0.1mm from the block which means that there will be slight leakage but this is necessary in order to allow printing on various 3D printers.   
There is one system INLET and 8 OUTLETS. The passages and valves are designed in such a way that the fluid entering the inlet exits from each outlet in consequitive pulses (starting from Outlet no. 8 to outlet No.1).   
The connectors are designed for 5mm rubber tube. There are 2 mounts for wall mounting via M4 Allen Screw (DIN 912 - ISO 4762). Alternatively there are side mounts for 4mm screws with 10mm screw-driver or tool acces holes at the oposite side. Finally there are 2 slots for easy hanging.   
It can be used for controlled and distributed lubrication (e.g. large bearings) or controller irrigation or any other purpose that requires multiple controller fluid distribution.
Designed for 3D printing, if properly modified can be produced with other more conventional methods as well.

comments.author: Doxin

comments.text: The cut view is missing a connection that is at another plane. Generally the flow forced the 1st valve to move thus allowing fluid to come out of port 8...then the valve is forced to move the other way and port 7 is open, this opens the passage for the 2nd valve to move and open the 6th port and so on. A constant flow leads to a constant periodic movement of the valves, of course with a phase shift. This forces the fluid to change passage and move from one opening to the other.

I made this compass to replace the one that comes with Windswept by dutchmogul. It is used as a counter to only allow the game to have 12 rounds. I wanted to add a little something of my own to the game.

I created this compass to have a similar style to vintage nautical compasses used on tall ships. A marker indicates the starting/end position. Note: You will need to color the needle to determine which way points North, or copy and modify the original compass model on TinkerCad.

I used tapered surfaces so using a dry-brush technique would highlight the horizontal lines stepping along the z axis of the print (a side effect from additive 3D printers) in an aesthetically pleasing way rather than showing flat surface with lines that could essentially go in any direction based on the settings of the slicer software.

You need:

  1. Paint (I used Artist's Loft Acrylic Paint)
    1. Yellow Ochre Deep
    2. Gold Metallic
    3. Silver Metallic
    4. Ivory lack
    5. Deep Red
  2. Brushes
    1. Sponge Brush
    2. Paint brush
  3. Sealer (I used Modpodge Hard Coat)
  4. Printed Parts

Paint

Dial

  1. Give base coat of Yellow Ochre Deep
  2. Drybrush with Gold
  3. Paint individual shafts Ivory Black carefully
  4. Paint top of "North" block Deep Red

Needle

  1. Give base coat of Ivory Black
  2. Paint one arrow Silver
  3. Paint a letter "N" in Ivory Black
    1. I used a toothpick to make it with lots of dotting

Seal

Seal the pieces so that the paint will not rub off when they are handled. In general, use a sponge brush to put a light layer of sealer over each piece. Use a paint brush to get into hard to reach areas. Make sure the clean the brushes before the sealer dries them together.

Needle

Find something round to stick through the needles hole, that gradually gets bigger, that can not go through the hole completely. Work the round stick to prevent the hole from getting smaller with the sealer, but make sure it will not end up glued to the needle.

Dial

Try to go very lightly on the center peg and platform that the needle will touch when the two pieces are assembled. Do not glob the sealer in this area.

Assemble

Assemble the needle onto the compass. You may find that the sealer made the hole too small. You may need to look into other options to make the hole bigger in the needle, or to sand some of the glue off around the dials peg.

I wanted to hang 2 files on the wood tool board in my small workshop.
I designed the model to do that.

Each slot is 6mm wide and 27mm long (30mm - 3mm chamfer).
Spacing between the 2 slots is 44mm to take file easily.
I used two 4x20mm screws to hold that on the wood board.

I wanted a better way of fine tuning the Z end stop. Trying to undo a nut and adjust each time was unreliable for me.

I run the nut up onto the adjusting bolt to help stabilize the adjustment knob. By lifting it above the bearing mounting bracket, you can rotate and adjust the height of the bolt.

It's got 12 stops that fit loosely against this bearing housing. This gives 30 degree adjustments to the height.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jgZUhLR9vSW

Printed mine with 0.2 mm resolution in ABS 220 degrees C, 25% infill on glass bed at 110 degrees C. My own preference is 4 layers before infill top and bottom.

Could easily be printing in PLA or other material, key is the side that touches the bed should be perfectly smooth and level to allow even adjustment.

It should fit somewhat loose to allow sliding up and down the bolt and nut.

This cockpit for the Ranger EX supports a Finwing 390 pan tilt, and has a shelf system for the electronics. I fit a Vector and a Tornado/Cyclops without issue. This design will be evolving but it already works perfectly as is.

Cut this from 3mm ply, screw and glue. Do a dry fit first and figure out your glue order; it's less messy that way. Shim the back with some foam as needed.

UPDATE: We've used this on a number of Rangers now and its a hit. Use the TALL posts so it clears the servo. Also you will want to tidy up the holes with a file depending on what bit your CNC used. Use a bit of foam to shim.

description.text:
When it came to designing the octopurse I kept buoyancy in mind, so the I made the base of the design as large as possible to help it float, I also made the internal body hollow to further provide buoyancy. To enable the design to hold money I added canister inside the octopus to contain the mass of coins. The legs of the octopus are separate to the main body as trying to print the design in one piece would have been difficult. The legs (tentacles) needed to be inserted in to the holes on the side of the octopus. The reason that I chose to design an octopus was that I wanted to design something associated with water. I designed the model using 3D CAD software. This is my first design uploaded to Thingiverse.
The lid is separate and allows you to insert the coins inside the octopurse. I then 3D printed my design to see if it worked. The reason that printed the legs separate to the main body was that the 3D printer created a lot of support material and the full model could not fit on to my 3D printer, so it was more beneficial make the main body as large as possible so that it could hold more coins and the print the legs separately. I added chamfers onto end of the legs to make it easyier to insert onto the main body of the octopurse. When it comes to 3D printing the model its best to lay legs to acheive the best quality and detail. The best shell thickness that I found to use was 1.6 mm making it still structurally sound and light weight. Setting your 3D printer speed to 50 mm per second should work well.
Test one - Total weight held = 800 Grams of coins
To improve the weight held I went back to the drawing board to find a way of adding more buoyancy to the design. I came up with adding two floats either side of the octopus, I designed the floats to look like toxic oil drums!
Test two - Total weight held = 1.218 KG of coins
My aim was to put as many coins on design without it sinking , which I accomplished in test two, plus the barrels assisted in balancing the octopus.
I designed the model using 3D CAD software and then 3D printed it to test it.

comments.text: Very impressive for your first design.  I really like its look!

title: LilyPad Decorative Holder and Buoyancy Test

description.text:
This is a LilyPad based candle holder and buoyancy demonstration. It uses modifiable ballasts to change the buoyancy of the assembly. The design was inspired in part from nature's lily pad and in part from concept cities that are designed to float on water. http://inhabitat.com/lilypad-floating-cities-in-the-age-of-global-warming/

This part was designed as a low scale learning model to teach and test buoyancy concepts. My hope is that parents and educators can use this thing to teach buoyant force aspects of science to the next generation of innovators.

This thing was made with PLA on a Replicator 2x using 2 shells and 10% infill.

The buoyant force pushing upward on the lilypad is generated from the air pocket made during the fabrication process of the ballasts. Since air is less dense than water, the displaced water causes and upward force to counter that of gravity pulling downward on the lily pad and the mass of the coins on top of it. As shown in the pictures, the bigger the ballast, the more weight, and more coins, the lily pad could hold without sinking. These concepts is what makes steel ships float.

All parts printed with PLA, 2 shells, and 10% infill. You may consider 0% or 5% infill.

Print the LilyPad Middle,( v2 has a removable thin square to prevent/minimize warping).

Print the Lily Pad top decoration, or make your own. If you make your own - the top hole has a diameter of 0.8 inches, I would recommend a bevelled edge and a diameter of ~0.077 inch

Print the Lily Pad bottom bottom ballasts either as a teaching aid as necessary for yourself to hold the weight as needed. If you want to modify and try different designs, the bottom connection has a diameter of 1 inch. I printed mine with the rounded part on the bottom to prevent support structures from being inside the connecting cavity.

Connect all the pieces top-middle-bottom. You have to remove some material if the clearances were to not designed or made with proper error.

author: chazaswell

description.text:
This is one of a series of educational displays I made for the Arcade Library in Sacramento to help teach people about 3D printing.

It can be difficult to explain important 3D printing concepts like the need for supports, what a raft is, what shells are, infill percentage, and the effects of changing the resolution.

Sometimes all you need is a visual aid to make things click.

This display illustrates what happens when you print something without supports... what supports and a raft look like... and the final product after the raft and supports have been removed.

See the instructions for details on how to make this display for your classroom, or anywhere else it will be useful.

I've also included the SketchUp files if you would like to make changes.

See the Infill Display I made here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:927750
And the Shell Display here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:927684

The cat model I used in this display was made by thingiverse user imaterialse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1283

The hardest part of printing these displays is printing the labels.

You will need to pick two colors, one for the background of the label and one for the letters.
Load the color you have chosen for the background of the label and start the print. I used the settings 0.3mm layer height, 2 shells, 5% infill for each of the labels. You will need to keep a close eye on your printer so you don't mess this up.
Once your printer has completed printing the background of the label and has started the first layer of the letters, select change filament from the menu on your 3d printer. Proceed to unload the filament and load the second color you have selected for the lettering. Then continue the print. Repeat these steps for each of the three display labels.

The rest is easy...

Print "Raft and Support Display Stand.stl" in the color of your choosing three times.
I used the settings: 2 shells, 10% infill and 0.3mm layer height.

Then print "The Cat.stl" three times:
-Once without any supports
-Twice with supports and raft.

Remove the raft and supports from one of the prints, and leave the other one alone.

Finally glue the whole thing together. Use the pictures as reference.
The glue I used is "Model & Hobby Cement" from the dollar store. It's strong but not so strong that you cannot get it apart if you make a mistake.

Enjoy! Teach and spread the knowledge of 3D printing!

For beginners.

Layer pitch is 0.3mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness.

No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT).

120 minutes to print. 30 minutes for shaping and constructing.
6m * 4colors for ABS.

Other parts,
some pins (ø2*6, SUS)
1 leather strap

How to use pins?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNg1lNYXcFk

In case of traditional machining, making accurate pin-holes on object is not so easy thing,
especially if the object is small, has irregular shape or the pin-hole is angled.
Because it needs additional assembling jigs to fix.

However, in case of 3D printing, it is pretty easy.
It does not need any other cost, except adding holes in 3D data.

The metal pins are enough accurate, so you can make both type of holes lock and roose easily.
Also it is much more strong than 3D printing materials, so you can make thin strut or axle.
Also it is enough cheap so you can bury under objects, or glue it.

Of course you can use screws. Actually screws are more usual in real world.
However you have to tap holes, you can not make loose screw or you can not joint objects face by face because it needs driver.

note. You need "reamer" and "drill chuck" to adjust holes.

author: Faze_eirt

description.text:
Simplfied model for my broken Miele washing machine pump door.
60% infill, use support material and 0.25 layer thikness for best result

This is a boat that I made for the Make It Float Challenge.
The boat is entirely 3D printed, at first I was thinking about maybe using different materials for the shafts for less friction, but it's more awesome when everything is 3D printed, easier for other people to replicate!
It's should be noted the one needs some weights in order to make it work. I used Swedish coins.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6HBbhRpqCjc

Solidworks were used to calculate the buoyancy, which was pretty easy. The hardest thing was to make the water wheel turn, I printed about 30 different water wheels before I got it right. The first water wheels didn't turn at all. But now it does!

The body parts on the boat are made with the help of an Xbox Kinnect, which I bought on ebay recently.
The head is mine, the hands are my fathers and the arms one of my friends. It's like frankenstein.

EDIT 2015-07-27 Fixed a small artifact on "Left_Arm.STL". Thanks mathgrrl, for the observation!

Read more about how I made it here:
http://3dprint.com/85013/make-it-sink-makerbot-float/
http://www.3ders.org/articles/20150728-swedish-student-filip-sjoo-designs-and-3d-prints-a-cool-automated-boat.html

I think one could easily understand how to assemble the beast when looking at the assembly called MAKE_IT_SINK.stl

Some things to think about:

♦ The plug need to be printed two times. You need two of them.

♦ I all parts can be printed without supports, however there are some bridging needed on the water wheel and on some other places.

♦ I printed everything without glue, but if something feels too loose for you, just glue it!

♦ The counter weights can be moved a little bit on their rods in order to optimize things.

♦ In the counter weight for the arms you need to but a fairly small coin to make it work, or just some other thing. The important thing is that it is in equilibrium.

Printer settings that I used:

Layer height: 0.2 mm
Fill Density: 100%
Print speed: 40 mm/s
Printing temperature: 210 C
Bed temperature: 65 C
Filament diameter: 1.75 mm
Flow: 100%
Nossle size: 0.4 mm
Retraction speed: 50 mm/s
Retraction distance: 4.5 mm

And the printer was an Aworldnet Havit A602 Reprap Prusa i3

I could not find a dial indicator mount that was easily printable and would accurately mount on my extruder (not sure if they changed the design recently) so I designed my own. It uses magnets to keep the mount stable on the extruder, but locates itself by hugging onto 3 bolts on the outside of the extruder. For reference, my SD3 bed had 0.31mm variance between the high and low point on the bed. Magnets used. (6.2mm OD)
http://www.amazon.com/dp/B001KV9RAW Dial indicator used
http://www.amazon.com/dp/B006YD7G36

After printing, drill the screw hugger holes with a 5.5mm drill bit. It will be a perfect and slightly tight fit, which is what you want. you might also need to slightly sand the dial indicator mount, but again, you want a very tight fit to keep it dimensionally stable. After printing, I can take the mount off the extruder, put it back on and be within a few hundredths of a mm. This makes it easy since you can find the nozzle contact point, zero the indicator and then you are just looking for the zero indication on the bed everywhere.   
You should probably print this with fairly thick walls to keep it rigid and use supports to keep the overhangs from sagging and changing the dimensions.

title: Bracket mount for 75mm wide Venetian blinds cover/panel/anything else

description.text: A simple mount for blinds with decorative edges and a curved hook for secure mounting.

This is a replacement for the broken mount for my blinds. It will fit a 75mm wide cover panel, and has a hook for hanging on the blinds head, or onto something else (with a ~6mm gap/thickness). Hope it helps! The long arm can be heated gently with a torch to bend it for a spring-loaded fit, but will also fit as-is.

Mount clamp for 25mm pipe

Mega Majora's Mask in High-Definition.
"HD-Mega" Desktop / Wall Edition, with 5mm LEDs
Pre-Alpha release (v0.0.0.1)

These "Thing" instructions are for making your very own nostalgic Majora's Mask, complete with surface finishing, mounting hardware, and cool NeoPixel LED electronics.

WARNING: This is an EARLY pre-alpha release! Please take all instructions with a grain of salt, as I'm releasing this larger model much sooner than I had planned. I have found myself not able to get the instructions/photos/build-process documented to the "polished" level I would have liked (yet) due to work obligations. Due to several requests for the larger "HD-Mega" version, I am releasing these files early so that they do not collect too much dust. My apologies for the rough instructions. I have printed the models, but that's about it... If you wish to print this model in it's early stage, good luck and please post your results. I will try to resume progress on this project in the future. GOOD LUCK!

Printer:

Custom Mendel 90 w/ E3Dv6 Hotend

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.40mm Nozzle, 0.2mm Layer Height

Infill:

10% Honeycomb

Notes:

I have printed several iterations of this mask at full scale to find print settings that work well on my printer (Cutom Mendel-90, single E3D extruder, SmoothieBoard, and Slic3R software). Primarily, I have warping issues with ABS on large prints and also find excessive PLA support material sometimes difficult to remove. These general constraints have led me through iterative design improvements to the model to optimize "troubled" overhang areas, producing a model that prints well with only a minimum amount of PLA support. I recommend that you use my print settings as a starting point, and make any adjustments from there that may be more appropriate for your printer (i.e. if you have dissolvable support material capability, you may wish to be more aggressive with the support). The following settings were essential for me to get good consistant prints of this model:

My recommended Slic3r 1.2.9 config files are available for PLA
for users that use Slic3R and have a 0.4mm nozzle. Just import the
config file into Slic3r, and then re-select your own personal printer
from the "printers" drop down box. The configuration assumes you have
a heated bed (if you don't, just disable that on the filament screen).

REQUIRED MATERIALS:

  • One 3D printer

Plastic Filament

  • One roll of opaque plastic filament (PLA highly recommended)
  • One roll of clear/translucent colorless plastic filament (t-glase highly recommended)
  • One roll of support material (if you have a dual extruder machine)

Optional: Print smoothing/finishing compound and consumables

  • One Box of Smooth-On XTC-3D Brush On Coating
  • One Box of sponge brushes
  • One Roll of wax paper
  • One Roll of aluminum foil
  • One pack of mixing sticks (wooden popcicle sticks)
  • One pack of small disposable platic cups

Optional: Electronics

  • Twenty-Eight Adafruit 5mm Diffused Neopixels
  • Two Adafruit Perma-Proto 1/2 Size Breadboards
  • Qty 1, Adafruit Pro Trinket - 5V 12MHz ($9.95 ea)
    https://www.adafruit.com/products/2000
  • Qty 1, Adafruit Pro Trinket LiIon/LiPoly Backpack ($4.95 ea)
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/2124
  • Qty 1, Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 2500mAh ($14.95 ea)
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/328
  • Micro USB wall charger
  • One roll of wire
  • One roll of solder

Tools

  • One soldering Iron
  • Your prefered tools for support removal (i.e. small pliers, dental pick, razor blade(s), etc)

PRINT THE FOLLOWING PARTS:

You will need to print the folllowing items in opaque PLA:

  • Qty 1, "Mask-v4.stl", Opaque ABS/PLA/etc.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1474804
    XYZ Print Dimensions:
    Printed as is: (223mm,161mm,135mm)
    Rotated 45 degrees about Z axis (197mm, 197mm, 135mm)
  • Qty 1, "Mask-PinSet-v4.stl", Opaque ABS/PLA/etc.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1474808
    XYZ Print Dimensions: (16mm,16mm, 8mm)

You will need to print the following items in translucent t-glase or translucent PLA:

  • Qty 1, "3mmLED-Horn-Set-v2.stl", Transparent ABS/PLA/etc.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1424350
    NOTE: You must scale the 3mm LED horns to 166.66% to fit the 5mm LED mask.

RECOMMENDED PRINT SETTINGS:

Opaque PLA:

  • brim_width = 0 (not really needed if you are using PLA)
  • cooling = 1 (if you have fans, use them for PLA)
  • fan_always_on = 1 (I keep mine on always for good measure)
  • infill_only_where_needed = 0 (always do full infill, as we are infilling at a very low density anyways)
  • layer_height = 0.2 (a layer height of 0.2mm is a good balance between quality and speed. Use your own judgement here)
  • raft_layers = 0 (if you are printing on glass; to get the best glued seam leave raft layers off.)
  • support_material = 1 (there are a few "problem" areas that need support, so we turn support on)
  • support_material_pattern = rectilinear (my personal support pattern preference)
  • support_material_spacing = 1 (my personal support material spacing preference)
  • support_material_threshold = 14 (we only want support for overhangs of 14 degrees or less in relation to the print bed to support problem ares, and minimizing excessive support generation and extra print time)
  • bottom_solid_layers = 3 (bottom layer will be three layer heights thick)
  • top_solid_layers = 3 (top layer will be three layer heights thick)
  • perimeters = 3 (outer shell will be three extrusion widths thick)
  • extra_perimeters = 1 (allow the slicer to add extra outer layers if needed)
  • fill_density = 10% (we don't need a lot of internal support)
  • fill_pattern = honeycomb (or any infil pattern suitable for very low infil densities)
  • external_fill_pattern = rectilinear (top and bottom layers)

Translucent t-glase or translucent PLA:

  • To help light travel through the horns, always print at the thickest layer height possible. Generally, this is 80% of whatever your nozzle size is (i.e. if you have a 0.4mm nozzle, print translucent material at 0.32mm layer height)
  • perimeters = 1 (we only want our exterior shells one extrusion width wide)
  • fill_density = 0% (turn off infill, we are printing hollow objects to help light travel through the printed parts)
    ** FOLLOW THE MANUFACTURES RECOMMENDATIONS FOR OTHER PRINT SETTINGS (i.e. print speed, etc)
    ASSEMBLY:

There are four small guide pins to temporarily hold the mask together (Mask-PinSet-v4.STL). These pins should just give you a snug fit, but still allow the mask halves to be easily separated. Depending on the tolerance of your printer; the pins may be too tight to easily insert into the holes. Don't force the pins, as you won't be able to easily separate and re-attach the two halves while applying glue. Scale the four pins down just a bit (95%?), re-print, and retry. It will only take a few minutes to reprint the 4 small pins.

Now that you have good alignment, separate the two halves leaving the guide pins in place in one of the mask halves. Now grab your favorite glue and apply an appropriate amount along the seam. Now firmly press the two mask halves together and clamp until dry.

If you want glowing horns, you will need to print the horns using a clear or translucent material. Cut a piece of Aluminum foil to 6mm x 12mm. Use a small piece of scotch tape to secure the foil to the outer surface of the 6mm long light pipe (bottom/center of the horn). The shiny side should be facing inward.

Next, insert a "large-guide-pin" into the base of the horn. Now press the horn and its guide pin into one of the masks horn sockets. The 54mm horn goes in the bottom socket, followed by 55.8mm horn, and so on until you get to the 62.4mm horn on the top of the mask. (Glue the horns in place only if they are loose). The large guide pins have an outside diameter of 12.6mm and the inside diameter of the horn socket is 12mm. So you should have a tight fit (use pliers if needed to compress the guide clip as you insert it into the horn). If the fit is to tight, sand the guide clip down.

Now grab your 5mm NeoPixel LEDs, insert them into the LED holes from the rear side of the mask, and secure with a drop or two of Super-Glue.

Electronic wiring instructions to follow... You should be able to find plenty of code examples on Google to get the NeoPixel LEDs up and running. Otherwise, hang tight and I'll get a proper write-up posted soon. :-)

DESK STAND:

Print the two "Desk Stand" parts, and then glue them together. The mask can be quickly removed from the desk stand and replaced, as the mask just rests on three prongs. There are corresponding sockets on the rear side of the mask.

comments.text:
SUPPORT GENERATION STRATEGY:
Overall, the mask "almost" prints well without the need for
supports. However, there are still a few problem areas that do
need support, regardless if you are printing the single horizontal
piece or the two separate left and right pieces vertically. In either
case, I would recommend generating support, with a low threshold
of 15 degrees (in relation to the print bed). This will prevent a lot
of unnecessary support from being generated, and will ensure the
main trouble areas are supported. Refer to the new picture for
example preview of supports (5th picture over).

comments.author: Gam3r2Xtreme

comments.text: "HD-Mega" is scaled up exactly 5/3 larger than "HD-Mini" (HD-Mini scaled to 166.66%).  That is from simply scaling the model up from 3mm holes up to 5mm holes.  I tried to keep the file size down, but at full scale anything less than 199MB seemed to start showing the faceted surface.  The "HD-Mega" version roughly covers an adult human face (with a fairly reasonable Interpupillary distance).  Unfortunately, the overall shape of the mask would make it difficult to wear "as-is" without adding some sort of foam backing to conform to the face.  The idea with the new screw holes at the center of the rear side of the mask, was to allow bolting the wall mount to the mask, before hanging on a wall screw like a picture.  You could also bolt the mask to the desk stand as well if desired.

title: Raven Version 1 Quad-Copter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
New version is now available. v2.0 of the raven.
Goto http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962361

A 3D Printed Quad Copter by Bad-Intel and Cyberpunk V2.0 . http://www.cyber-punk.info

It is a design that was built for testing flight duration and with a 4S 6000mah battery. Gives me about 50 mins flying time.

Have done test flights and all works rather well.

All parts are attached together with aluminum square tube. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=40657

The 3D printed parts should slot into the aluminum square tube.

Requires drilling, nuts and bolts to put it all together. The holes to be drilled are already part of the 3D print and just need to be drilled out to size.

I use two body plates to extend the length of the copter. But for smaller copters, just use one body plate.

The front has a hole for a CCD camera, while the back has a hole for a antenna to fit.

The unit in the photo uses 4x MT2213-935KV MultiStar Motors with a 4S 6000mah battery. (Gives me about 60 mins flying time)

Will publish the canopy and all terrain landing gear soon.

For personal use only.
Copyright of http://www.bad-intel.com and http://www.cyber-punk.com

author: C3Design

description.text:
This is a stubby flashlight that holds twenty-seven 5mm LEDs and has a cutout on the bottom for a 12mm size pushbutton switch. Both the LED and switch mounts are removable and are secured via a number of small screws.

You'll need to figure out how much voltage you'll be using and the appropriate resistor(s) for your LEDs.

UPDATE: I've included a three-switch bottom plate for those using RGB LEDs (or similar). I've also included an extension that can be printed in case you need to make your flashlight longer (just glue it to the main body).

Twenty-seven 5mm LEDs are required along with a 12mm sized switch and several small screws. Also a battery holder and appropriate battery and resistors are required.

The LED holes are sized at 6mm to give some wiggle room when installing them. Simply tack them in place with glue or similar.

remixed_from.author: Thesaint7811
remixed_from.title: Linear bearing system for 1" aluminium extrusion

description.text:
I came across some 1.5" T-Slot and decided to make a rail for a future laser cutter upgrade.

The model is scaled for 1.5" (38.1mm) so if you have 1" T-Slot scale it by 66.66% and for 20mm T-Slot scale by 52.49% however you will need to drill out the holes for the sliders for whatever hardware you use. My 1.5" version is for 6-32 machine screws. The cap screw for the rail was 1/4-20.

The slider pad was made using a dollar store HDPE cutting board ripped into a 1.5" strip and slowly stripped down on a table saw until it was a good slip fit. You could easily export the pad model for 3D printing.

I recommend putting some thin foam tape along the sides of the sliders against the frame. That will provide a squishy spring and keep them easily removeable.

A derivative of MakeALot and chylld's previous work.
I wanted a more tweakable model, and decided to switch to a different coordinate system as my brain doesn't bend around toroids as easily as MakeALot's!
It's classed as a toy because I spend more time finding cool settings than I do compiling and printing variants (which is quite a claim if you increase the number of spheres and decrease the $fa parameter too far!)
Enjoy! 2011-06-21 Update
I've also implemented the algorithm in Art of Illusion, as it allows much higher resolution STLs to be generated for much lower computational cost.

Tweak the parameters to your liking in OpenSCAD, compile and render to CGAL, export as STL, slice in your 3D printing software and output on your 3D printer. Simples. Alternatively:
In Art of Illusion, install the STL transformation tool, then from the Tool menu, choose Edit Script and paste in the contents of Toroidal Toy.bsh. Save the script as "Toroidal Toy"
Choose Toroidal Toy from the Tools>Scripts list. Use the sliders to set the parameters then click OK to see your new toy.
File > Export > STL and proceed as before.
