The Phoenix is the main Interplanetary spaceship for the G-Force team in the battle to protect Earth against the forces of planet Spectra. It can deploy four smaller vehicles, each operated by one team member, a starfighter, a high speed assaault vehicle, a motorcycle and an all-terrain scout vessel. It is able to travel underwater and in the atmosphere, as well as in deep space. The Phoenix’s primary weapon was a large supply of rockets. It also occasionally flaunted a powerful solar-powered energy blaster, but the most powerfull weapon in its arsenal is to transmutate itself into pure energy (called the "Fiery Phoenix" effect) that can destroy anything in it´s path. The Phoenix is currently stationed at Neptune Base, an underwater secret installation disguised as an atoll somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean.
(model sourced from https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=500a2bdbf29acbe5a6618cd4237f8a8 )

description.text:
This model was done from very basic brochure illustrations and a crude waterlines drawing. Lots of photoreferences were also used plus my personally having seen dozens of these boats hauled out for weeks at a time to deal with osmosis blisters in the boatyards. The reconstruction of the 3d model was done originally for a old school modelmaker who needed the waterlines for what is known as a 'lift model' much like what was done in the 18th century in the shipyards. Today this technique is know as 'bread and butter' modeling as it uses horizontal planks around 1/2" sawn to the wl shapes and then stacked up and pinned together with vertical dowels. Grinders, rasps and sanders take out the 'stairsteps' of the layers and then it is faired, primed and painted although I like contrasting woods for the layers and finished with lacquer or varnish clear. 

 A friend is now milling the model at 18" on his home made cnc router and I plan on submitting it to Shapeways for printing on demand there.

https://sketchfab.com/models/18990829ea5340fb88c1e0b9d506a856#

Look here for starters and I'll update soon!

This is a fishing bobber that I have designed for the Make It Float Challenge. It has taken many revisions to get a model that I'm happy with. My major revisions for the bobber and lock are shown with earliest revs on the left and finished revisions further to the right. Although all of the bobbers and locks worked, my revisions were aimed at becoming lighter, stronger and easier to print.
Incorporating the extrusion in the bobber to other hollow models it is likely that you could make almost anything into a Bobber with the same locking mechanism.

After printing the Bobber and its Lock you only have to insert the lock until it clicks into the bobber. At this point the lock can't be removed, this design keeps you from dropping and losing the lock. That is the only step needed to assemble the bobber. To attach it to fishing line you just have to place the line in the notch located between the two arms or the lock and push the lock until it clicks again. To release the lock, simply squeeze the two arms and pull the lock out.

title: Hydroponics nutrient solution refiller (for sprout tray)

description.text:
This part is for used together with "Bottle Connector with funnel by cgongora69" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902607) to maintain nutrient solution level in sprout tray at 5-6mm or 12mm height.

** UPDATE (6 Sep 2015) : I've added the 12mm version. Recommed to print this version if you use sponge as grow medium.

Print with this setting. 0.2mm, 15% infill 2 shells.

Fill 500ml bottle with nutrient solution. Put the Bottle Connector cap to the bottle and place it bottom up onto the refiller. Make sure that you've already put some nutrient solution in sprout tray before you do this.

By this way it will create vacuum inside the bottle. When nutrient solution is down below the cap, it will drain out some solution to refill the tray automatically. Likely the pet's automatic water refill tray.

description.text: Located in Chicago, Illinois. A public sculpture by Indian-born British artist Anish Kapoor, that is the centerpiece of AT&T Plaza at Millennium Park in the Loop community. Constructed between 2004 and 2006, the sculpture is nicknamed The Bean because of its shape.

Assumptions:
-All calculations assume air is of negligible mass

Design goals:
-Maximize hydrodynamic efficiency
-Build a boat straight from the imagination
-Create a boat that can actually be 3D printed successfully

Design explanation:
-From some basic research on hull design, multihull boats gain many advantages over monohull boats, such as increased stability and improved speed.
http://www.sailingissues.com/yachting-guide/catamarans.html

Final Design Calculations:
Total boat volume= 10172.3717 mm3 => 101.72 cm3
Mass of boat=107.82 g
Force of gravity on boat=1056.67 mN

Hull volume (just plastic) = 8992.8251 mm3 => 89.93 cm3
Void volume in hull = 3573.6095 mm3 => 35.74 cm3
Total hull displacement = 125.7 cm3
Buoyant force due to hull (assuming air is of negligible mass) = 1231.57 mN

Assuming quarters have a mass of 5.670g, the boat could theoretically hold 30 quarters safely

Dimensions:
Hull length = 9.3 cm, large hulls
5.08 cm, small hulls

-Boat hull comments:

  • had to scale up by 1.5x to get printable parts
    -Just a prototype, a little back heavy on the connector (caused the back to fill up with water but still floated kind of)

Assembly:
-Haven’t had a chance to print the full design, but the hull and bottoms can be attached together

description.text:
This handy little hanger keeps the dish brushes organized and able to drain water into the sink. Yes, the design is pretty specific to the brushes pictured, but keep in mind that the Top component is detachable, and can be replaced by whatever hook system you'd like to create.

Any replacement Top requires as an interface a 1/8 in thick material with a slot that's .3 in wide and 1/4 in tall, as seen in the screenshot.

The suction cups utilized are the 5 lb. Clear-Plastic Suction-Cup Hooks (3-Pack), purchased from the Home Depot. The neck diameter (the part that interfaces with the Base) should be around 7/16 in.

Please print, share your results and enjoy your well organized kitchen sink.

Print one of each: Base, Arm and Top, and assemble as seen in the pictures above, making use of the provided slots. The print seen here was made on a MakerBot Replicator 2 with Makerbot White PLA filament at standard settings, resulting in a great fit.

Slide suction cups in to the Base and affix to a clean, smooth surface (kitchen sink). Wetting the lower surface of the suction cups slightly ensures your Kitchen Brush Hanger will stay in place better than dry.

Located in Brussels, Belgium. Building originally constructed for Expo 58, the 1958 Brussels World's Fair. Designed by the engineer André Waterkeyn and architects André and Jean Polak. Stainless steel clad spheres are connected so that the whole forms the shape of a unit cell of an iron crystal magnified 165 billion times. It is a museum.
